quest_title: Deuterium is an isotope of hydrogen having mass of 2.01470 amu. Finding B.E in Mev of this isotope is

explanation_txt: Solubility of \(Al(OH)_{3} \) is lesser than \(Zn(OH)_{2} \) . And species whose solubility is lesser gets precipiated first as this equilibrium state easily shifts in backward direction.

quest_title: In a group, metallic character ___ with the inrease in atomic number.
explanation_txt:
Metallic character decreases as you move across a period in the periodic table from left to right. This occurs as atoms more readily accept electrons to fill a valence shell than lose them to remove the unfilled shell.

Metallic character increases as you move down an element group in the periodic table. This is because electrons become easier to lose as the atomic radius increases, where there is less attraction between the nucleus and the valence electrons because of the increased distance between them.
question_plain_title: In a group, metallic character ___ with the inrease in atomic number.
explanation_plain_text:
Metallic character decreases as you move across a period in the periodic table from left to right. This occurs as atoms more readily accept electrons to fill a valence shell than lose them to remove the unfilled shell.

Metallic character increases as you move down an element group in the periodic table. This is because electrons become easier to lose as the atomic radius increases, where there is less attraction between the nucleus and the valence electrons because of the increased distance between them.

quest_title: How many numbers of five digits can be formed from the numbers 2, 0, 4, 3, 8 when repetition of digits is not allowed?
explanation_txt:
The number of numbers including the one starting from zero, \(N = {}^5P_5 = 5! = 120 \)

The numbers starting from zero \( n = {}^4P_4 = 4! = 24 \)

So, the numer of numbers is \( N - n =96 \)

explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{vol}}{\sec }=\cfrac{\pi P r^{4}}{8 \eta l}\)

quest_title: An object whose image is formed on screen at 12cm from the lens. When the lens is moved 2cm farther from the object, the screen must be moved 2cm closer to the object to refocus it. The focal length of lens is
explanation_txt:
1st case

\(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{\mathrm{uv}}{\mathrm{u}+\mathrm{v}}=\cfrac{12 \mathrm{u}}{12+\mathrm{u}}\)

2nd case

\(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{(\mathrm{u}+2)(\mathrm{v}-2)}{\mathrm{u}+2+\mathrm{v}-2}=\cfrac{(\mathrm{u}+2) 10}{12+\mathrm{u}}\)
\(\mathrm{Now}, \cfrac{12 \mathrm{u}}{12+\mathrm{u}}=\cfrac{10(\mathrm{u}+2)}{12+\mathrm{u}}\)
or, \(12 \mathrm{u}=10 \mathrm{u}+20\)
\(\mathrm{u}=10 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{f}=\cfrac{12 \times 10}{22} = 5.6 cm\)

quest_title: The frequency of 3\({}^{rd}\) harmonics of a wire of 0.2m long having tension 2N and diameter 0.5mm where density of material is 8000kg/m\({}^{3}\) is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{f} &=3 \mathrm{f}_{0}=3 \times \cfrac{1}{2 l} \sqrt{\cfrac{\mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{A} \rho}}=\cfrac{3}{2 l} \sqrt{\cfrac{\mathrm{T}}{\cfrac{\pi \mathrm{d}^{2}}{4} \rho}} \\ &=\cfrac{3}{2 \times 0.2} \sqrt{\cfrac{4 \times 2}{\pi\left(0.5 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2} \times 8000}} \\ &=268 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A hollow charged metal sphere has a radius \(\text{r}\). If the potential difference between its surface and a point at distance 3\(\text{r}\) from the centre is \(\text{V}\), then the electric intensity at distance 3\(\text{r}\) from the centre is
explanation_txt:
Given that
\(\begin{array}{l}{\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\left(\cfrac{q}{r}-\cfrac{q}{3 r}\right)=V} \\ {\text { Or, } \cfrac{2 q}{4 \times 3 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}=V} \\ {\therefore \cfrac{q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}=\cfrac{3}{2} V \ldots \ldots \ldots .(1)}\end{array}\)
Now,
\(\begin{aligned} E &=\cfrac{q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}\left(3 r^{2}\right)}=\cfrac{q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r} \cdot \cfrac{1}{9 r} \\ E &=\cfrac{q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}\left(3 r^{2}\right)}=\cfrac{3 V}{2} \times \cfrac{1}{9 r} \text { from }(1) \\ \therefore E &=\cfrac{V}{6 r} \end{aligned}\)

explanation_txt:

Dielectric has \(K>1\), therefore electric field decreases.

quest_title: The resistance per unit length of a potentiometer wire 10m long is one Ohm per meter. A resistance box and a 2 volt accumulator are connected in series with the potentiometer wire. The value of resistance in resistance box to have a potential drop of 1mV in the potentiometer wire is
explanation_txt:
Total resistance of pot. Wire \((\mathrm{R})=10 \times 1 \Omega / \mathrm{m}\) \(=10 \Omega\)

Let \(\mathrm{R}\) be the required resistance

Current n the circular \(\mathrm{I}=\cfrac{2}{R+10}\)

p.d. in pot. Wire 1\(\mu \mathrm{V}\)

The potential across pot. Wire \((\mathrm{v})=2 \mathrm{v}-1 \mathrm{mv}\)

\(=1999 \mathrm{MV}\)

Again

\(\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{IR}\)

\(1 \mathrm{mv}=\cfrac{2}{R+10} \times 10\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}=19990 \Omega\)

quest_title: The distance of two points on the axis of a magnet from its centre is 10 cm and 20 cm respectively. The ratio of magnetic intensity at these points is 12.5 : 1. The length of the magnet will be
explanation_txt:
Magnetic field intensity at a point lying in the extended axis of magnet having length \((2l), \, B=\cfrac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \cfrac{2 M d}{\left(d^{2}-l^{2}\right)^{2}}\)

\(\cfrac { B _ { 1 } } { B _ { 2 } } = \cfrac { d _ { 1 } } { d _ { 2 } } \left( \cfrac { d _ { 2 } ^ { 2 } - l ^ { 2 } } { d _ { 1 } ^ { 2 } - l ^ { 2 } } \right) ^ { 2 } \Rightarrow \cfrac { 12.5 } { 1 } = \cfrac { 10 } { 20 } \left( \cfrac { 0.4 - l ^ { 2 } } { 0.1 - l ^ { 2 } } \right) ^ { 2 }\)

\(\Rightarrow l = 0.05 \mathrm { m }\)

Hence, length of magnet \(= 2 l = 0.1 \mathrm { m }=10 \mathrm { cm }\)

quest_title: The work done in deflecting a small magnet of magnetic moment 10 Am\({}^{2}\) through 180\(^\circ\) from uniform magnetic field of strength 0.4 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) T is
explanation_txt: \( \begin{align} W & = MB(1-\cos \theta) \\ & = 10 \times 0.4 \times 10^{-4} (1 - \cos 180^ \circ) \\ & = 10 \times 0.4 \times 10^{-4} \times 2 \\ & = 8 \times 10^{-4} \, J \end{align}\)
question_plain_title: The work done in deflecting a small magnet of magnetic moment 10 Am through 180 from uniform magnetic field of strength 0.4 10 T is
ans1_plain_text: 8 10 J
ans3_plain_text: 4 10 J

quest_title: For a body moving with relativistic speed, if the velocity is doubled, then
ans2_txt: Its linear momentum will be less than double
ans3_txt: Its linear momentum will be more than double
explanation_txt:
Relativistic momentum \(= \cfrac { m _ { 0 } v } { \sqrt { 1 - v ^ { 2 } / c ^ { 2 } } }\)

If velocity is doubled then the relativistic mass also increases. Thus, value of linear momentum will be more than double.
question_plain_title: For a body moving with relativistic speed, if the velocity is doubled, then
explanation_plain_text:
Relativistic momentum

If velocity is doubled then the relativistic mass also increases. Thus, value of linear momentum will be more than double.
ans2_plain_text: Its linear momentum will be less than double
ans3_plain_text: Its linear momentum will be more than double

quest_title: A 10g stone tied by nylon thread of 0.5 m length and 2mm diameter is rotated in horizontal circle. The maximum permissible strain is not exceed 0.5% then angular velocity of stone if Y of nylon is 2\(\times\)10\({}^{9}\)N/m\({}^{2}\)
explanation_txt:
Stress \(=\mathrm{Y} \times\) strain
or, \(\mathrm{T}=\mathrm{Y} \times\) strain \(\times \mathrm{A}=\mathrm{m} l \omega^{2}\)
\(\therefore \omega=\sqrt{\cfrac{Y \times \text { strain } \times A}{m l}}\)
question_plain_title: A 10g stone tied by nylon thread of 0.5 m length and 2mm diameter is rotated in horizontal circle. The maximum permissible strain is not exceed 0.5% then angular velocity of stone if Y of nylon is 210N/m
explanation_plain_text:
Stress strain
or, strain

quest_title: If the diameter of a capillary tube is doubled, then the height of the liquid that will rise is
explanation_txt:
Capillary rise (h) \(=\cfrac{2 T }{r d g}\)

\(h \propto \cfrac { 1 } { r }\)

\(\therefore\) height of liquid that will rise becomes half as the diameter of the tube becomes twice.
question_plain_title: If the diameter of a capillary tube is doubled, then the height of the liquid that will rise is
explanation_plain_text:
Capillary rise (h)

height of liquid that will rise becomes half as the diameter of the tube becomes twice.

explanation_txt:
\(\overline { v ^ { 2 } } \propto T\) (Kelvin Scale).

\(\therefore\) Absolute temperature can be calculated by mean square velocity of gases.

quest_title: Calorimeters are made of which of the following
explanation_txt: Calorimeter is used to measure heat exchange among bodies or heat capacity of different materials. For this, heat exchange should be quick and heat loss should be avoided. Since metals have high conductivity of heat, they can exchange heat quickly. Therefore, calorimeters are made by conducting materials.
question_plain_title: Calorimeters are made of which of the following
explanation_plain_text: Calorimeter is used to measure heat exchange among bodies or heat capacity of different materials. For this, heat exchange should be quick and heat loss should be avoided. Since metals have high conductivity of heat, they can exchange heat quickly. Therefore, calorimeters are made by conducting materials.

quest_title: A closed bottle containing water at 30°C is carried to the moon in a space-ship. If it is placed on the surface of the moon, what will happen to the water as soon as the lid is opened
explanation_txt: Boiling occurs when the vapour pressure of liquid becomes equal to the atmospheric pressure. At the surface of moon, atmospheric pressure is zero, hence boiling point decreases and water begins to boil at 30°C.

explanation_txt:
Incident ray and finally reflected ray are parallel to each other means \(\delta = 180^{\circ}\)

From \(\delta = 360 - 2 \theta \Rightarrow 180 = 360 - 2 \theta \Rightarrow \theta = 90 ^ { \circ }\)

quest_title: An object is placed at a distance of 20 \(\textit{cm}\) from a convex lens of focal length 10 \(\textit{cm}\). The image is formed on the other side of the lens at a distance
explanation_txt:
From lens formula,

\(\cfrac{1}{f} =\cfrac{1}{v} + \cfrac{1}{u} \) [Given \(u=20\)\(\textit{cm}\), \(f=10\)\(\textit{cm}\), \(v=?\)]

\(\therefore \cfrac{1}{10} =\cfrac{1}{v} + \cfrac{1}{(20)} \Rightarrow v=20\, cm\)

quest_title: What causes changes in the colours of the soap or oil films for the given beam of light?
explanation_txt:
By Chanli44

Light is reflected from both the inner and outer surface of the soap bubble. These reflected lights interfere constructively and destructively based on the path difference between them. Thickness of film determines path differences for different wavelength of light and therefore the type of interference and the colour of the soap bubble.


By Threetwoone
question_plain_title: What causes changes in the colours of the soap or oil films for the given beam of light?
explanation_plain_text:
By Chanli44

Light is reflected from both the inner and outer surface of the soap bubble. These reflected lights interfere constructively and destructively based on the path difference between them. Thickness of film determines path differences for different wavelength of light and therefore the type of interference and the colour of the soap bubble.


By Threetwoone

quest_title: The figure shows a double slit experiment P and Q are the slits. The path lengths PX and QX are \(n\lambda\) and \((n+2)\lambda\) respectively, where n is a whole number and \(\lambda\) is the wavelength. Taking the central fringe as zero, what is formed at X?
explanation_txt:
Path difference \(=QX-PX=(n+2)\lambda - n\lambda=2\lambda\) which is multiple of \(\lambda\)

So, bright fringe is obtained at X.

explanation_plain_text:
Path difference which is multiple of

So, bright fringe is obtained at X.

quest_title: \(V _ { o }\) and \(V _ { E }\) represent the velocities, \(\mu _ { o }\) and \(\mu _ { E }\) the refractive indices of ordinary and extraordinary rays for a doubly refracting crystal. Then
ans1_txt: \(V _ { o } \geq V _ { E } , \mu _ { o } \leq \mu _ { E }\) if the crystal is calcite
ans2_txt: \(V _ { o } \leq V _ { E } , \quad \mu _ { o } \leq \mu _ { E }\) if the crystal is quartz
ans3_txt: \(V _ { o } \leq V _ { E } , \mu _ { o } \geq \mu _ { E }\) if the crystal is calcite
ans4_txt: \(V _ { o } \geq V _ { E } , \mu _ { o } \geq \mu _ { E }\) if the crystal is quartz
explanation_txt:
In double refraction light rays always splits into two rays (O-ray & E-ray). O-ray has same velocity in all direction but E-ray has different velocity in different direction.

For calcite \(\mu _ { e } < \mu _ { 0 } \Rightarrow v _ { e } > v _ { 0 }\)

For quartz \(\mu _ { e } > \mu _ { 0 } \Rightarrow v _ { 0 } > v _ { e }\)
question_plain_title: and represent the velocities, and the refractive indices of ordinary and extraordinary rays for a doubly refracting crystal. Then
explanation_plain_text:
In double refraction light rays always splits into two rays (O-ray & E-ray). O-ray has same velocity in all direction but E-ray has different velocity in different direction.

For calcite

For quartz
ans1_plain_text: if the crystal is calcite
ans2_plain_text: if the crystal is quartz
ans3_plain_text: if the crystal is calcite
ans4_plain_text: if the crystal is quartz

quest_title: Electron of velocity 10\({}^{7}\)m/s enters in a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density 0.1T. The angle between the direction of field and initial path of electron is 25\({}^{o}\) then pitch of helical path is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \text { Pitch }(\mathrm{P}) &=v \cos \theta \cdot \cfrac{2 \pi \mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{Be}} \\ &=10^{7} \times \cos 25^{\circ} \times \cfrac{2 \pi}{1.8 \times 10^{11} \times 0.1} \\ &=3.2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A cork of density d\({}_{1}\) float in liquid of density d\({}_{2}\) at 0\({}^{0}\)c. If the coefficient of volume expansion of cork and liquid are \(\gamma\) and 100\(\gamma\) then cork will just sink in liquid at t\({}^{o}\)c then d\({}_{2}\)/d\({}_{1}\) is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{c}}^{\mathrm{t}}=\mathrm{d}_{l}^{t}} \\ {\text { or, } \cfrac{d_{1}}{1+\gamma t}=\cfrac{d_{2}}{1+100 \gamma t}}\end{array}\)

\(\therefore \cfrac{\mathrm{d}_{2}}{\mathrm{d}_{1}}=\cfrac{1+100 \gamma t}{1+\gamma t}\)

quest_title: Light from an object are focused at a point. A convex lens of focal length 24cm is placed at 24cm from point at which light is focused. The point at which light converges now changes by
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{u} &=-24 \mathrm{cm} \\ \mathrm{v} &=\cfrac{\mathrm{fu}}{\mathrm{u}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{24(-24)}{-24-24}=12 \mathrm{cm} \\ \Delta \mathrm{v} &=24-12=12 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: Figure shows three points A, B and C in a region of uniform electric field \(\vec { E }\). The line AB is perpendicular and BC is parallel to the field lines. Then which of the following holds good where \(V _ { A } , V _ { B }\) and \(V _ { C }\) represent the electric potential at points A, B and C respectively
explanation_txt:
Points A and B lie in the same plane which is perpendicular to electric field. Therefore, they lie in the same potential.

Furthermore, potential decreases in the direction of electric field. So, the potential at C is less than potential at A or B.
question_plain_title: Figure shows three points A, B and C in a region of uniform electric field . The line AB is perpendicular and BC is parallel to the field lines. Then which of the following holds good where and represent the electric potential at points A, B and C respectively
explanation_plain_text:
Points A and B lie in the same plane which is perpendicular to electric field. Therefore, they lie in the same potential.

Furthermore, potential decreases in the direction of electric field. So, the potential at C is less than potential at A or B.

quest_title: A rectangular loop of sides 8 cm and 2 cm having resistance of 1.6 \(\Omega\) is placed in a magnetic field of 0.3 T directed normal to the loop. The magnetic field is gradually reduced at the rate of 0.02 T/S. How much power is dissipated by the loop at heat?
explanation_txt:
We know that the induced emf \((E)\) is equal to the product of rate of change of magnetic field area. Hence
\(\begin{array}{l}{E=(0.02) \times\left(8 \times 2 \times 10^{-4}\right)} \\ {E=3.2 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{V}} \\ {i=\cfrac{E}{R}=\cfrac{3.2\times 10^{-5}}{1.6}=2 \times 10^{-5} A} \\ {\therefore \text { Power loss }=i^{2} R=\left(2 \times 10^{-5}\right)^{2} \times 1.6} \\ \quad{\text { Power loss }=i^{2} R=6.4 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{watt}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: A rectangular loop of sides 8 cm and 2 cm having resistance of 1.6 is placed in a magnetic field of 0.3 T directed normal to the loop. The magnetic field is gradually reduced at the rate of 0.02 T/S. How much power is dissipated by the loop at heat?
explanation_plain_text: We know that the induced emf is equal to the product of rate of change of magnetic field area. Hence
ans1_plain_text: 1.6 10 Watt
ans2_plain_text: 3.2 10 Watt
ans3_plain_text: 6.4 10 Watt
ans4_plain_text: 12.8 10 Watt

quest_title: An alternating voltage is represented as \(E = 20 \sin 300 t\). The average value of voltage over one cycle will be
explanation_txt:
\(V_{avg}=\cfrac{\int Vdt}{\int dt}\)

Emf of the above signal is symmetric about origin. Green region consists of negative emf which cancels out to that of red region. Therefore, the average value of the signal is zero.
